35. The metres found in Plautus are chiefly ianibie, trochaic, anapaestic, cretio, and bacchio. A peculiarity of iambic‚ trochaic, and anapaestic verses is that they are, at least in Greek poetry, ineasured by dipodies, i.e. pairs of feet, instead of by single feet, each dipody havingmne main and one subordinate ictus. Accordingly, a verse of four feet is called a dimeter (instead of a tetrameter), one of six feet a trimeter (instead of a hexameter), ete. Frequently, however, and especially with reference to early Latin poetry, these verses are called qualorum-ii, senarii, etc„ names given them solely with reference to the number of feet contained in each, the distinctions between the odd and the even feet having been, for the nlost part, lost sight of by early Latin poets.
